metadata.title: Mortgage Rates Drop 19 Basis Points This Week (January 2026)
metadata.metaDescription: Mortgage rates fell 19 basis points this week. See current rates for 30-year, 15-year, and refinance options, plus calculate your potential savings.

content.headline: Mortgage Rates Fall 19 Basis Points: What It Means for Your Home Purchase
content.intro:
If you've been waiting for mortgage rates to ease before buying a home or refinancing, this week brings welcome news. Average mortgage rates dropped by 19 basis points, offering borrowers some breathing room after months of elevated borrowing costs.

Whether you're a first-time homebuyer calculating affordability or a current homeowner considering a refinance, understanding how these rate movements affect your monthly payment can help you make a smarter financial decision.

sections.heading: Current Mortgage Rates: January 18, 2026
sections.content:
Here's where mortgage rates stand as of January 18, 2026:

Loan TypeCurrent RateWeekly Change
30-Year Fixed6.62%-0.19%
15-Year Fixed5.89%-0.15%
30-Year FHA6.25%-0.17%
30-Year VA6.18%-0.16%

These rates represent national averages. Your actual rate depends on your credit score, down payment, loan amount, and the lender you choose.

sections.heading: Why Did Rates Drop This Week?
sections.content:
Several factors contributed to this week's rate decline:

  • Treasury yield movement: The 10-year Treasury yield, which heavily influences mortgage rates, retreated from recent highs as investors reassessed inflation expectations.
  • Economic data: Recent reports suggesting a cooling labor market gave the Federal Reserve room to maintain its current policy stance.
  • Market expectations: Investors are pricing in the possibility of Fed rate cuts later in 2026 if inflation continues its gradual decline.

While a 19-basis-point drop may seem modest, on a $400,000 mortgage it translates to approximately $45 in monthly savings—or over $16,000 across a 30-year loan.

sections.heading: Should You Lock Your Rate Now?
sections.content:
The million-dollar question: Are rates heading lower, or is this a good time to lock?

Rate timing is notoriously difficult to predict. Consider these factors:

  • Your timeline: If you're closing within 30-60 days, locking now protects you from potential increases.
  • Rate lock costs: Longer lock periods typically cost more. A 60-day lock might add 0.125% to your rate compared to a 30-day lock.
  • Float-down options: Some lenders offer float-down provisions that let you benefit if rates drop further after you lock.

If current rates allow you to comfortably afford your target home, locking makes sense. Trying to time the absolute bottom often leads to missed opportunities.

sections.heading: How This Affects Your Buying Power
sections.content:
Lower rates directly expand what you can afford. Here's how the 19-basis-point drop affects monthly payments on different loan amounts:

Loan AmountPayment at 6.81%Payment at 6.62%Monthly Savings
$300,000$1,958$1,924$34
$400,000$2,611$2,565$46
$500,000$3,264$3,206$58
$600,000$3,917$3,847$70

These savings compound over time. On a $500,000 loan, you'd save nearly $21,000 in interest over 30 years with the lower rate.

sections.heading: Is Refinancing Worth It Now?
sections.content:
If you purchased your home when rates peaked above 7%, this week's drop might make refinancing attractive. The general rule: refinancing makes sense when you can lower your rate by at least 0.5% to 0.75%.

Before refinancing, calculate your break-even point. If closing costs total $6,000 and you save $150 monthly, you'll recoup those costs in 40 months. Plan to stay in your home longer than that? Refinancing likely pays off.

Don't forget to factor in:

  • Current home equity (most lenders require 20% for the best rates)
  • Your credit score (has it improved since your original loan?)
  • Remaining loan term (refinancing to a new 30-year loan restarts your amortization clock)

sections.heading: What to Expect in the Weeks Ahead
sections.content:
While no one can predict rates with certainty, several upcoming events could influence mortgage rate direction:

  • January 29: Federal Reserve meeting and policy statement
  • February 7: January jobs report
  • February 12: Consumer Price Index (CPI) inflation data

Strong economic data or stubborn inflation could push rates back up. Conversely, signs of economic cooling might accelerate the downward trend.

Most forecasters expect rates to remain in the 6% to 7% range through the first half of 2026, with gradual improvement possible in the second half if inflation continues easing.

keyTakeaways: Mortgage rates dropped 19 basis points this week, with 30-year fixed rates now averaging 6.62%
The rate drop saves approximately $46/month on a $400,000 loan—over $16,000 across 30 years
Consider locking your rate if current payments fit your budget; timing the market bottom is risky
Refinancing may be worthwhile if you can reduce your rate by 0.5% or more and plan to stay in your home long enough to recoup closing costs
content.conclusion:
This week's 19-basis-point drop offers a meaningful opportunity for both homebuyers and refinancers. While rates remain higher than the historic lows of 2020-2021, they've improved from recent peaks.

Use our mortgage calculator below to see exactly how current rates affect your specific situation. Whether you're buying your first home or considering a refinance, running the numbers helps you make a confident decision.

faqSchema.question: What are current mortgage rates in January 2026?
faqSchema.answer: As of January 18, 2026, the average 30-year fixed mortgage rate is 6.62%, down 19 basis points from the previous week. The 15-year fixed rate averages 5.89%.

faqSchema.question: How much can I save with the 19 basis point rate drop?
faqSchema.answer: On a $400,000 mortgage, a 19 basis point rate reduction saves approximately $46 per month, or about $16,560 over the life of a 30-year loan.

faqSchema.question: Should I lock my mortgage rate now or wait?
faqSchema.answer: If current rates allow you to comfortably afford your target home, locking makes sense. Trying to time the absolute bottom is risky. Consider a float-down option if available, which lets you benefit if rates drop further after locking.

faqSchema.question: Is now a good time to refinance my mortgage?
faqSchema.answer: Refinancing typically makes sense when you can lower your rate by at least 0.5% to 0.75%. Calculate your break-even point by dividing closing costs by monthly savings to determine if refinancing pays off based on how long you plan to stay in your home.

faqSchema.question: What factors affect my personal mortgage rate?
faqSchema.answer: Your actual mortgage rate depends on your credit score, down payment amount, loan amount, property type, loan type (conventional, FHA, VA), and the lender you choose. National average rates serve as benchmarks, but individual rates vary.

calculation.formula: M = P * [r(1+r)^n] / [(1+r)^n - 1], where P = principal, r = monthly rate, n = number of payments
calculation.logic: Calculate monthly payment at both rates using standard amortization formula, then compute the difference. Multiply monthly savings by total months for lifetime savings.
